nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) is pseudoscience because it has produced few falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
Peters and collaborators claim mainstream economic theory is flawed and propose ergodicity economics as a conceptually clearer alternative

Consider a two-asset continuous-time portfolio model where risky asset follows geometric Brownian motion with drift mu and volatility sigma, safe asset yields risk-free rate r, initial wealth normalized to 1, and portfolio fraction theta is continuously rebalanced
EE prescription: maximize long-run geometric average growth rate, which in the model yields the objective mean r + (mu - r) theta - 0.5 sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r)/sigma^2

Mainstream expected utility theory (EUT) prescription with CRRA utility leads to objective V(theta) = r + (mu - r) theta - 0.5 gamma sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal portfolio theta = (mu - r)/(gamma sigma^2)
Result: EE and EUT predictions coincide in this model when relative risk aversion gamma equals 1 (log utility), otherwise they differ and EE corresponds to log-utility special case

Testability claim: For the portfolio model one can in principle estimate mu, r, sigma and test whether observed investor portfolios match EE prediction theta = (mu - r)/sigma^2 or EUT proportionality; more complex consumption-investment models are similarly in principle testable under EUT

EE meets multiple Wikipedia indicators of pseudoscience: (i) vague or untestable claims, (ii) improper collection of evidence, (iii) limited peer review by economists, (iv) absence of substantive progress beyond historical results, (v) personalization of critiques, and (vi) use of misleading language

Evidence of lack of generalizable testable development: Peters and collaborators note future generalizations beyond multiplicative dynamics but little progress has been published in 12 years and core results largely restate earlier works (Kelly, Latan√©)

Evidence supporting pseudoscience indicators: examples include grandiose claims without concrete testable applications, citation of out-of-context literature, limited publication in economics journals, reliance on a small set of experimental studies that have been criticized, and vague terminology in abstracts
Conclusion: Until EE provides clear, falsifiable, and novel empirical predictions tested by relevant economic experts, it should be treated with skepticism and not considered established science
